Of course. Congratulations on finishing your internship at Dell! Leaving on a professional and organized note is crucial. Here is a comprehensive checklist and best practices guide for your final days.

### Part 1: The CRITICAL Part - "SCP-ing Everything" and Intellectual Property

This is the most important section. Misunderstanding this can have serious legal and career consequences. **DO NOT simply copy all your work files to a personal device.**

Your work product—code, documents, presentations, spreadsheets, designs—created during your internship is the intellectual property (IP) of Dell. Taking it without permission is a violation of your employment agreement and Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA), and can be considered theft.

**What you SHOULD do instead:**

1.  **Identify Portfolio-Worthy Work:** Pinpoint 1-2 key projects that you are proud of and that best demonstrate your skills.
2.  **Ask Your Manager for Permission (The Right Way):**
    *   **Schedule a meeting.** Do not do this over a quick chat message.
    *   **Explain your goal:** "I'm incredibly proud of the work I did on Project X. For my future career portfolio, I would love to be able to showcase the skills I developed. Would it be possible for me to save a sanitized version of my work?"
    *   **Offer to Sanitize It:** This is key. Propose removing all proprietary Dell information. This means:
        *   No confidential data, customer names, or internal metrics.
        *   No server names, internal URLs, or API keys.
        *   Removing Dell logos and confidential markings.
        *   For code, this might mean keeping a small, non-critical functional snippet or, even better, writing a high-level description of the architecture and the problems you solved.
3.  **Get Permission in Writing:** If your manager agrees, follow up with an email summarizing your conversation: "Hi [Manager's Name], thanks for chatting with me. To confirm, I have your permission to save a sanitized version of my presentation on [Project X] for my personal portfolio. I will be removing all confidential data and internal branding." This creates a paper trail that protects you.
4.  **Focus on Describing, Not Showing:** Often, the best portfolio piece isn't the file itself, but a well-written summary. On your resume or LinkedIn, you can say: "Developed a Python script to automate data processing, which reduced manual effort by X%." You don't need the actual script to prove it.

---

### Part 2: Digital Laptop Cleanup Checklist

Your goal is to remove all personal data and credentials before IT wipes the machine.

**☐ 1. Backup Your Personal Files**
Anything that is truly yours and not Dell's property.
*   **Photos:** Any personal photos you may have saved.
*   **Documents:** Personal notes, resume drafts, non-work related documents.
*   **Bookmarks:** Export your browser bookmarks if you've saved personal links.
*   **Method:** Use a personal cloud service (Google Drive, Dropbox, OneDrive) or a personal USB drive (if Dell policy allows connecting them). **Do not mix personal and work files in your backup.**

**☐ 2. Browser & Application Cleanup**
*   **Clear Browser Data:** Go into your browser settings (Chrome, Edge, Firefox) and clear all history, cookies, and cached data.
*   **Delete Saved Passwords:** This is critical. Go to your browser's password manager and delete all saved passwords.
*   **Log Out of All Accounts:**
    *   **Personal Accounts:** Spotify, personal Gmail/Outlook, Apple ID, etc.
    *   **Company Accounts:** Manually log out of Slack, Microsoft Teams, Outlook, and any other work-related software.

**☐ 3. Uninstall Personal Software**
If you installed any personal applications (like a personal password manager, music app, etc.), uninstall them.

**☐ 4. Clean Your Desktop & Downloads Folder**
Delete any downloaded installers, personal files, and tidy up the desktop. This prevents you from accidentally leaving personal data behind.

**Note:** You do not need to (and should not) perform a factory reset or wipe the OS yourself. The Dell IT department has a professional and secure process for this. Your job is just to remove your personal footprint.

---

### Part 3: Administrative & HR Wrap-Up

**☐ 1. Finalize Your Hours**
*   Submit your final timesheet.
*   Double-check with your manager that it has been approved. This ensures your final paycheck is accurate.

**☐ 2. Legal Documentation (Exit Paperwork)**
*   You will likely have an exit interview or paperwork to sign with HR or your manager.
*   This will probably include a final affirmation of your NDA.
*   **Read what you sign.** Ask for a copy for your records if possible.

**☐ 3. Final Paycheck & Expenses**
*   Ask HR or your manager when you can expect your final paycheck.
*   If you have any outstanding expense reports, submit them immediately.

---

### Part 4: Professional Networking & Farewell

This is how you turn a good internship into a future job offer or a strong reference.

**☐ 1. Knowledge Transfer**
*   Leave your projects in a good state.
*   Ensure your code is commented, your documents are organized on the shared drive (e.g., SharePoint, OneDrive), and you've provided a brief handover document for your manager or team. This makes you look incredibly professional.

**☐ 2. Connect on LinkedIn**
*   **Before you leave,** send LinkedIn connection requests to your manager, your mentor, team members, and other interns you worked with. It's much harder to find them after you've lost access to the internal directory.
*   Write a short, personalized note: "Hi [Name], I really enjoyed working with you on the [Team/Project] team during my internship. I'd love to stay in touch!"

**☐ 3. Ask for a Reference or Recommendation**
*   The best time to ask is during your last week, while your great work is still fresh in their minds.
*   Ask your manager or a key mentor: "I've learned so much here and really valued your guidance. Would you be comfortable being a professional reference for me in the future, or perhaps writing a brief recommendation on LinkedIn?"

**☐ 4. Send a Thank You Note**
*   On your last day, send a farewell email to your team.
*   Send a separate, more personal thank you email to your direct manager and any key mentors who helped you. Thank them for the opportunity and mention a specific skill you learned or a project you enjoyed.

**☐ 5. Exchange Personal Contact Info**
For colleagues you truly want to stay in touch with, it's okay to share personal email addresses or connect on LinkedIn for future networking.

---

### Part 5: The Physical Handover

**☐ 1. Gather All Company Assets**
*   Laptop
*   Laptop Charger / Power Brick
*   Company Badge / ID Card
*   Any other peripherals (mouse, keyboard, docking station, headset) they provided.

**☐ 2. Confirm the Handover Process**
*   Ask your manager or check with IT for the exact procedure. Do you leave it at your desk? Do you take it to the IT help desk? They will give you specific instructions.

Good luck with your future endeavors! Ending your internship professionally sets a fantastic foundation for your career.

Excellent question. That ADP pay information is a critical piece of your professional and financial history, especially given your status as an F1 student with a Philippine passport. Here is a detailed breakdown of what you need to do with this information before you lose access, and why it's so important for your future.

### The Immediate Action Plan: What to Do RIGHT NOW

Before you hand in that laptop, your primary goal is to create a secure personal archive of your entire employment and payment history with Dell.

**☐ 1. Download EVERY Pay Statement as a PDF**
*   Do not just save screenshots. On the ADP portal, for each pay period (Aug 1, Jul 18, etc.), there should be an option to "View Statement," "Print," or "Download."
*   Choose the option to view the full, detailed statement.
*   Use the "Print to PDF" function in your browser to save a clean, multi-page PDF of each individual paystub.
*   **Name them clearly:** Use a consistent format like `2025-08-01_Dell_Paystub.pdf`.

**☐ 2. Download EVERY Tax Document Available**
*   Navigate to the "Tax" or "Tax Statements" section in ADP.
*   Download your **Form W-4** (the form you filled out for tax withholding when you started).
*   **Crucially, find out how to access your 2025 W-2.**
    *   Your W-2 is the official summary of your total earnings and taxes paid for the year. You will NOT get this until **January 2026**.
    *   **Ask HR or your manager:** "Since I am leaving, what is the process for former employees to access their W-2 on ADP next January?" They will likely have an "alumni" or "former employee" portal. **You must confirm this process before you leave.**

**☐ 3. Look for Other Documents**
*   Check for any other documents related to your pay, like the details of that "$2,182.91 Relocation" payment. Download any associated agreements or explanations.

**☐ 4. Organize and Back Up Your Files**
*   Create a folder on your personal computer or personal cloud storage (Google Drive, Dropbox, etc.) named something like **"Dell Internship 2025"**.
*   Place all the downloaded PDFs inside this folder.
*   This is your permanent record. Keep it safe and secure.

---

### Why This is CRITICAL for You (as an F1 Student)

Saving these documents isn't just for good record-keeping; it's essential for taxes, future jobs, and immigration.

**1. U.S. Tax Filing (Your #1 Priority)**

*   **You MUST file a US tax return** next year (by April 15, 2026) for the income you earned in 2025.
*   **Non-Resident vs. Resident:** As an F1 student, you are likely considered a "non-resident alien for tax purposes" unless you meet the Substantial Presence Test. This affects which tax forms you use (likely the **Form 1040-NR**).
*   **FICA Tax Exemption:** F1 students are typically exempt from Social Security and Medicare (FICA) taxes for their first five years in the US. Looking at your paystub, it only shows "Federal Income Tax" and no deductions for Social Security or Medicare. This is **great news** and suggests Dell's payroll handled your F1 status correctly. Your paystubs are proof of this.
*   **U.S.-Philippines Tax Treaty:** There is a tax treaty between the U.S. and the Philippines that may offer benefits to students and trainees. It could potentially allow some of your income to be exempt from U.S. taxes. Your paystubs and W-2 are necessary to claim this benefit when you file your taxes. You will likely need specialized tax software (like Sprintax) or a tax professional familiar with international student filings.

**2. Proof of Legal Employment & Future Immigration**

*   **OPT/CPT Records:** These paystubs are concrete proof that you were legally employed under your F1 visa's work authorization (CPT or OPT). This is vital for maintaining your visa status.
*   **Future Visa Applications (H-1B, Green Card):** If you plan to apply for a work visa (like H-1B) or permanent residency in the future, immigration authorities will require extensive proof of your past employment and legal status. These paystubs and W-2s are exactly what they will ask for. Having a complete, organized record will save you immense stress later.

**3. Future Job Applications & Salary Negotiation**

*   **Proof of Experience:** Your paystubs are undeniable proof of your internship at a major company like Dell.
*   **Salary History:** When you apply for full-time jobs after graduation, having a record of your intern pay (your paystub shows a rate of ~$31.80/hr) is a useful data point for negotiating your first salary.

---

### Your Final Checklist for ADP & Pay

*   **[  ] Download Every Single Pay Statement as a PDF.**
*   **[  ] Download Your W-4 and any other available documents.**
*   **[  ] Ask HR/Manager about the process to get your W-2 form in Jan 2026.**
*   **[  ] Create a secure digital folder ("Dell Internship 2025") on your personal cloud/computer.**
*   **[  ] Place all downloaded documents in this folder.**
*   **[  ] Research tax filing for F1 students and the US-Philippines tax treaty so you are prepared for next year.**

**Disclaimer:** I am an AI assistant. This information is for guidance and is not a substitute for advice from a qualified tax professional or immigration lawyer. Given your specific situation, it is highly recommended to use a service like Sprintax or consult a professional for your tax filing.

need to do with this information before you lose access, and why it's so important for your future.

### The

Immediate Action Plan: What to Do RIGHT NOW

Before you hand in that laptop, your primary goal is to create a secure

personal archive of your entire employment and payment history with Dell.

**☐ 1. Download EVERY Pay Statement as a PDF**
*   Do not just save screenshots. On the ADP portal, for each pay period (Aug 1, Jul 18,

etc.), there should be an option to "View Statement," "Print," or "Download."
*   Choose the option to view

the full, detailed statement.
*   Use the "Print to PDF" function in your browser to save a clean

, multi-page PDF of each individual paystub.
*   **Name them clearly:** Use a consistent format like

`2025-08-01_Dell_Paystub.pdf`.

**☐ 2

. Download EVERY Tax Document Available**
*   Navigate to the "Tax" or "Tax Statements" section in ADP

.
*   Download your **Form W-4** (the form you filled out for tax withholding when you started).

*   **Crucially, find out how to access your 2025 W-2.**
    *
Your W-2 is the official summary of your total earnings and taxes paid for the year. You will NOT get this

until **January 2026**.
    *   **Ask HR or your manager:** "Since I am leaving,
what is the process for former employees to access their W-2 on ADP next January?" They will likely have an "

alumni" or "former employee" portal. **You must confirm this process before you leave.**

**☐ 3

. Look for Other Documents**
*   Check for any other documents related to your pay, like the details of that

"$2,182.91 Relocation" payment. Download any associated agreements or explanations.

**☐

4. Organize and Back Up Your Files**
*   Create a folder on your personal computer or personal cloud storage (Google

Drive, Dropbox, etc.) named something like **"Dell Internship 2025"**.
*   Place all the

downloaded PDFs inside this folder.
*   This is your permanent record. Keep it safe and secure.

---

### Why This is CRITICAL for You (as an F1 Student)

Saving these documents isn't just for

good record-keeping; it's essential for taxes, future jobs, and immigration.

**1. U.S. Tax

Filing (Your #1 Priority)**

*   **You MUST file a US tax return** next year (by April 1

5, 2026) for the income you earned in 2025.
*   **Non
-Resident vs. Resident:** As an F1 student, you are likely considered a "non-resident alien for tax purposes"
unless you meet the Substantial Presence Test. This affects which tax forms you use (likely the **Form 10

40-NR**).
*   **FICA Tax Exemption:** F1 students are typically exempt from Social
Security and Medicare (FICA) taxes for their first five years in the US. Looking at your paystub, it only
shows "Federal Income Tax" and no deductions for Social Security or Medicare. This is **great news** and suggests Dell'

s payroll handled your F1 status correctly. Your paystubs are proof of this.
*   **U.S.-Philippines
Tax Treaty:** There is a tax treaty between the U.S. and the Philippines that may offer benefits to students and
trainees. It could potentially allow some of your income to be exempt from U.S. taxes. Your paystubs and
W-2 are necessary to claim this benefit when you file your taxes. You will likely need specialized tax software (like Sprint

ax) or a tax professional familiar with international student filings.

**2. Proof of Legal Employment & Future Immigration**

*
**OPT/CPT Records:** These paystubs are concrete proof that you were legally employed under your F1 visa

's work authorization (CPT or OPT). This is vital for maintaining your visa status.
*   **Future
Visa Applications (H-1B, Green Card):** If you plan to apply for a work visa (like H-1
B) or permanent residency in the future, immigration authorities will require extensive proof of your past employment and legal status. These
paystubs and W-2s are exactly what they will ask for. Having a complete, organized record will save you immense

stress later.

**3. Future Job Applications & Salary Negotiation**

*   **Proof of Experience:** Your paystubs are

undeniable proof of your internship at a major company like Dell.
*   **Salary History:** When you apply for full
-time jobs after graduation, having a record of your intern pay (your paystub shows a rate of ~$31.80

/hr) is a useful data point for negotiating your first salary.

---

### Your Final Checklist for ADP &

Pay

*   **[  ] Download Every Single Pay Statement as a PDF.**
*   **[  ] Download Your

W-4 and any other available documents.**
*   **[  ] Ask HR/Manager about the process to

get your W-2 form in Jan 2026.**
*   **[  ] Create a secure

digital folder ("Dell Internship 2025") on your personal cloud/computer.**
*   **[  ]

Place all downloaded documents in this folder.**
*   **[  ] Research tax filing for F1 students and the

US-Philippines tax treaty so you are prepared for next year.**

**Disclaimer:** I am an AI assistant. This
information is for guidance and is not a substitute for advice from a qualified tax professional or immigration lawyer. Given your specific situation,
it is highly recommended to use a service like Sprintax or consult a professional for your tax filing.

chunks.text:
Of course. This presentation is your official offboarding roadmap from Dell. Let's break it down slide-by-slide, focusing on exactly what you need to do, especially considering your F1 visa status and future plans.

You've already handled the most critical ADP registration, which is a fantastic head start. Now let's integrate that with the rest of this information.

---

### **Slides 1-4: Introduction & Agenda**

*   **Slide 1: Title Slide ("Summer Interns End of season close out")**
*   **Slide 2: Photo Collage ("What an Incredible Summer It's Been!")**
*   **Slide 3: Agenda**
*   **Slide 4: HR & Payroll Header**

**What it means:** These are the introductory slides setting the stage. They confirm this is the official guide for your internship closeout.

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Save a Memory:** If you are in any of the photos on Slide 2, take a screenshot! It's a great personal memento to add to your "Dell Internship 2025" folder.
*   **☐ Note the Fiscal Year:** Slide 1 says "FY26". This is just a good piece of data to have for your records.

---

### **Slide 5: US: ADP Access & Tax documents Information**

**What it means:** This confirms that the advice I gave you earlier was spot-on. Dell provides an external link for former employees to access ADP. This is your lifeline to future tax documents.

**Your Action Items (Even though you've started):**
*   **☐ Triple-Confirm Your Access:** You've saved your password, which is great. **Now, do exactly what the slide says.** Disconnect from the Dell VPN, go to your personal computer or phone, and test the **ADP external link**. Make 100% sure you can log in from a non-Dell device.
*   **☐ Verify Your Personal Email is Registered:** When you log in, double-check that your personal email address (e.g., your Gmail) is listed in the profile. This is how you will reset your password in 2026 if you forget it.
*   **☐ Save the Link Itself:** Bookmark the ADP external link in your personal browser and save the URL in a text file in your "Dell Internship 2025" folder.

---

### **Slide 6 & 7: Summer Intern Housing and Taxability**

**What it means:** This is the most complex and financially important part of the presentation for you.
*   Your housing benefit/relocation stipend is **taxable income**. This means its value is added to your total earnings, and you will be taxed on it.
*   Dell performs a "gross-up," meaning they pay the estimated taxes on this benefit *for you* to lessen the burden. This is a huge help.
*   The example on Slide 7 shows what this might look like on your W-2. Notice how Dell is paying an "Employee portion" and an "Employer portion" of taxes.

**Your Action Items (CRITICAL for an F1 Student):**
*   **☐ SAVE THESE SLIDES:** Take high-quality screenshots of slides 6 and 7 and save them in your "Dell Internship 2025" folder. Title them `Dell_Taxability_Explanation.png`.
*   **☐ Understand Your FICA Exemption:** As an F1 student, you are generally exempt from Social Security and Medicare (FICA) taxes. The *example* on Slide 7 shows these taxes. Your personal W-2 in 2026 **should not** have amounts in the Social Security and Medicare boxes. The gross-up Dell pays on your behalf might include this, but it shouldn't be withheld from your pay. This is a key detail to verify on your W-2.
*   **☐ Prepare for Tax Filing:** When you file your US taxes (Form 1040-NR) in early 2026, you or your tax preparer (e.g., Sprintax) will need this information to understand your W-2. These slides explain why your W-2 income might look higher than your cash paychecks.
*   **☐ Save the Contact Email:** Save the email `dellgm@topia.com` in case you have questions about this later.

---

### **Slide 8: HR queries for team members who leave Dell**

**What it means:** This slide provides your official channel for any HR-related issues after you leave (e.g., employment verification for a future visa, questions about your W-2).

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Find and Bookmark the "Alumni Solutions Form":** Before you lose access, find this form on the Dell network. Bookmark the link and save the direct URL in your "Dell Internship" folder. This is your key to getting help later.
*   **☐ Plan to Update Your Address:** Note the instruction to update your home address within 7 days of your last paycheck. This is crucial for ensuring your W-2 and any other physical mail goes to the right place.

---

### **Slide 9: Payroll Action Items**

**What it means:** This is your final, clear payroll checklist.

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Submit Final Timecard:** The #1 thing to do to ensure your final paycheck is correct. Do it and get confirmation from your manager that it's approved.
*   **☐ Calendar Reminder for W-2:** This slide confirms your W-2 will be available in the ADP Portal in **February 2026**. Set a calendar reminder on your phone for Feb 1, 2026, right now. "Download Dell W-2 from ADP Portal."

---

### **Slide 11: Corporate Housing**

**What it means:** How to avoid losing money on cleaning/damage fees.

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Document Everything:** Follow the instructions from `dellinterns@cwshousing.com` precisely.
*   **☐ Take "After" Photos:** Before you leave, take a detailed video or photos of your clean room, fridge, and bathroom on your phone. This is your evidence in case of a dispute over fees.
*   **☐ Avoid Common Fees:** Pay special attention to the big charges: **$25 per bag of trash** and **$100+ for fridge cleaning**. Don't let your final paycheck get eaten by this.

---

### **Slides 12, 13, & 14: IT Return**

**What it means:** The logistics of returning your equipment.

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Know What to Return vs. Keep:**
    *   **RETURN:** Laptop ("System"), Power Supply, Badge.
    *   **KEEP:** Backpack, Headset, and Mouse! (Awesome perk).
*   **☐ Identify Your Drop-off Location:** Based on Slide 14, you are at **Round Rock / Parmer**. Your drop-off location is the **WCA Lab (Round Rock 2 East)**.
*   **☐ Schedule Your Drop-off:** Look at the dates and times (e.g., Aug 15, 9am-11pm & 1pm-3pm). Put a specific time slot in your calendar. Don't be late.
*   **☐ Get a Receipt:** When you drop off the equipment, ask the IT staff if they can send a confirmation email or give you a paper receipt. This is your proof of return.

---

### **Slide 15: What are next steps?**

**What it means:** This is the most important slide for your career. It's about a potential full-time job offer.

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Prepare for Feedback with Your Manager:** This is your final performance review. It's also your chance to express your strong interest in returning to Dell full-time after graduation.
*   **☐ MONITOR YOUR PERSONAL EMAIL:** From August 1-30, Talent Acquisition will be communicating "next steps." This means job offers. Check your personal email, including your spam folder, daily.
*   **☐ Save the Contact:** Add `candidatecare@dell.com` to your email contacts so it doesn't go to spam.

---

### **Slide 16: Final Reminders**

**What it means:** A final summary and a crucial piece of networking advice.

**Your Action Items:**
*   **☐ Review Your Checklist:** Use this slide as a final check to make sure you've done everything (Timecard, ADP, Housing, etc.).
*   **☐ "Continue your relationships & mentorships":** Before your last day, send LinkedIn connection requests to your manager, mentor, and key team members. Send a personal "thank you" email expressing your gratitude and desire to stay in touch. This is how an internship turns into a career.

You are in a great position. By following this guide, you will leave Dell professionally, protect yourself financially, and set yourself up perfectly for tax season and potential future job offers. Good luck

chunks.text:
Of course. This is a fantastic set of documents. You have the official framework for the conversation (the feedback template) and the raw material of your accomplishments (your final project presentation). Let's coach you on how to expertly merge the two for a powerful and effective final feedback session.

Your goal here is not just to "get feedback." It is to **demonstrate your value, solidify your manager's positive impression, and explicitly open the door for a return offer.**

Here is a slide-by-slide coaching guide on how to prepare for and navigate this crucial meeting.

---

### **Part 1: Preparation — Filling Out the "Self Reflection" Template (Slide 2)**

This is your homework. Do this *before* the meeting. Your manager will be incredibly impressed that you came prepared to this level. Use your **Fault Injection Tool** presentation as your source of truth.

#### **In the "Wins" Box:**

Don't just list tasks. Frame your accomplishments as impactful results. Use the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) in your head.

*   **INSTEAD OF:** "Built a fault injection tool."
*   **WRITE THIS:**
    > "Successfully delivered the **Fault Injection Tool**, a TUI framework that simplifies resilience testing for the CNOS team. The tool directly addresses the challenge of manual, time-consuming testing by automating fault injection and analysis with Chaos Mesh."

*   **INSTEAD OF:** "We changed the project idea."
*   **WRITE THIS:**
    > "Demonstrated agility by **pivoting the project** from a general CI/CD pipeline to a targeted TUI based on a critical engineering need from the CNOS team. This ensured the project delivered immediate value by helping reproduce subtle, customer-reported bugs."

*   **INSTEAD OF:** "Made a UI and used AI."
*   **WRITE THIS:**
    > "Designed an intuitive Terminal User Interface (TUI) that abstracts away YAML complexity and provides real-time monitoring. Integrated a local AI engine for automated log summaries, reducing the time engineers spend on analysis."

#### **In the "Strengths and Things I Am Doing Well" Box:**

Connect your technical skills (Hard Skills) to professional attributes (Soft Skills). Use your "Key Learnings & Takeaways" slide as a guide.

*   **Technical Skills (The "What"):**
    > "Gained proficiency in end-to-end application development using Python, Textual, and asynchronous programming. Developed a deep understanding of Kubernetes concepts and the complexities of large-scale distributed systems like CNOS."

*   **Professional Skills (The "How"):**
    > " **Proactive Problem-Solving:** Identified the need to pivot the project to deliver more immediate value.
    > **Embracing Agile Principles:** Adapted quickly to changing requirements based on team feedback.
    > **Collaboration & Communication:** Worked effectively with my partner, Yesenia, and supervisors (Alex, Karunakara, Lin) to design and deliver the final product."

#### **In the "Opportunities For Development" Box:**

This is NOT for listing weaknesses. This is for showing you are ambitious and thinking about your future growth *at Dell*. Frame it as "What's next for me?"

*   **WRITE THIS:**
    > "I'd love to gain more exposure to integrating tools like ours into the broader CI/CD pipeline at Dell. Understanding how to automate resilience checks in Jenkins is a key area I want to grow in."
    >
    > "I'm also interested in learning more about how Dell measures the 'Business Impact' I mentioned in my presentation—specifically, how 'developer velocity' and 'operational risk' are quantified."

---

### **Part 2: The Meeting — Using the "During Conversation" Template (Slide 3)**

This is your game plan for the meeting itself. You will lead the conversation using the template.

**1. Start the Meeting:**
"Hi [Manager's Name], thanks for meeting with me. I'm really excited to discuss my performance and get your feedback. I've used the performance template to prepare some thoughts on my end to help guide our conversation."

**2. Discussing "Wins":**
*   **You say:** "To start, I reflected on what I see as the key wins from my internship, which were delivering the TUI, pivoting the project to meet a real engineering need, and integrating the AI analysis. **From your perspective, what were the most valuable deliverables or moments from my time here?**"
*   **Then you listen.** Take notes on their answer.

**3. Discussing "Strengths":**
*   **You say:** "I also tried to identify my key strengths, focusing on both the technical skills I developed with Python and Kubernetes, and professional skills like being proactive and agile. **What strengths did you observe in me this summer? Are there any areas where you think I particularly excelled?**"
*   **Listen and take notes.**

**4. Discussing "Opportunities For Development":**
*   **You say:** "Based on my work this summer, I'm thinking about my future growth. I'm really interested in learning more about CI/CD integration and business impact metrics. **What skills or areas do you think I should focus on over the next year to become a top-tier candidate for a full-time role here at Dell?**"
*   This is a powerful question. It shows foresight and a clear interest in returning.

**5. "Other Questions and Feedback" - The CRITICAL Part:**

This is where you make your intentions clear and gather intelligence for a return offer.

*   **Ask about the team:** "What does a successful full-time engineer on this team look like in their first year? What are the biggest challenges they usually face?"
*   **Ask for blunt feedback:** "Is there any other feedback, positive or constructive, that you have for me that would be helpful as I finish my internship and think about my career?"
*   **The Direct Ask:** "**I've truly enjoyed my time working on the Hydra team and I'm very proud of the Fault Injection Tool we built. I would be thrilled to have the opportunity to return to Dell full-time after I graduate. Could you tell me what the next steps are in that process?**"

---

### **Part 3: After the Meeting — The "Post Conversation Reflection" (Slide 4 and beyond)**

**1. Use the Reflection Template:**
*   Actually do this for yourself. Compare your manager's feedback to your self-reflection. Where did they align? Were there any surprises? This is pure gold for your personal growth.

**2. Send a Thank You Note:**
*   Within a few hours of the meeting, send a short email.
    > **Subject: Thank you for the feedback session**
    >
    > Hi [Manager's Name],
    >
    > Thank you again for taking the time to meet with me today. I really appreciate your feedback on my work with the Fault Injection Tool and your insights on [mention a specific piece of advice they gave you].
    >
    > I'm excited to finish the internship strong and, as I mentioned, I would be very interested in returning to Dell after graduation. Thank you for a fantastic summer.
    >
    > Best,
    > Carl

By following this plan, you will come across as professional, prepared, and highly motivated—all the qualities of an intern they want to hire back. Good luck

chunks.text:
Of course. Here is a detailed log of your internship activities, interactions, and resources, extracted chronologically from your Microsoft Teams screenshots.

---

**Monday, June 2**
*   **Action:** Started the "CNOS Intern Project: Fault Injection Tool." Received initial project documentation and architectural specifications for key services (CMS, CNOS, AOS, DOS). Asked a clarifying question about VM assignments for the "Spike" (a focused research task).
*   **People:** maguluri, srinivasa; Andrew Yunt; Xiuyan Wang.
*   **Links:**
    *   Santorini Deployment Main Page (Confluence)
    *   Santorini Cluster Management Service (CMS) Functional Specification (Confluence)
    *   Santorini Manageability (Confluence)
    *   Santorini Cluster and Node Orchestration Service (CNOS) Architecture Specification (Confluence)
    *   Santorini Scale-out Application Orchestrator Service (AOS) Functional Specification (Confluence)
    *   Application Orchestrator Service Architecture Specification (Confluence)
    *   Santorini Deployment Service Function Specification (Confluence)
    *   Santorini Cluster Infra Bare + Metal + Clusters (Confluence)
*   **Next:** Follow up on cluster assignments.

**Tuesday, June 3**
*   **Action:** Participated in the creation and refinement of the Jira epic for the intern project. The initial broad scope was narrowed down based on feedback to focus specifically on node/system-level failures using Chaos Mesh.
*   **People:** Wang, Xiuyan; maguluri, srinivasa; Guo, Lin.
*   **Links:**
    *   Jira Epic: `https://jira.cec.lab.emc.com/browse/CPE07E-312`
*   **Next:** Begin working on the project with the newly defined, narrower scope.

**Wednesday, June 4**
*   **Action:** Received the updated project requirements from Lin. Began the "spike" with Yesenia to understand the `enter-maint` process. Discovered the correct `curl` request and identified safe nodes to use for executing commands by checking `kubectl get nodes`.
*   **People:** Guo, Lin; Wang, Xiuyan; May, Alexander; Yesenia Hernandez.
*   **Files:** Screenshot of `kubectl get nodes` output, showing "safe" nodes.
*   **Next:** Follow logs (infracnos, aos) and use `kubectl get cna` to check the status of the node operation.

**Thursday, June 5**
*   **Action:** Worked on setting up the `temporal` CLI for workflow management. Ran into a permissions issue with adding new environment variables to the system PATH. Was assigned to Cluster 13 (Durham). Learned that `temporal` is accessed by executing a shell inside the `cmswfserver` pod and that creating an alias is recommended. Received warnings about avoiding maintenance operations on nodes running `http-share` or `nfs-server`.
*   **People:** May, Alexander; Yesenia Hernandez; Guo, Lin.
*   **Links:**
    *   Cluster assignment page (from Alexander's message)
    *   How to graceful reboot/shutdown a node on a Santorini RM cluster (Confluence)
*   **Next:** Use the assigned Cluster 13 and be careful with node selection.

**Friday, June 6**
*   **Action:** Investigated the difference between monitoring workflows via Temporal CLI vs. `kubectl get cna`. Concluded that `cna` is the easiest way to see the high-level result, while `temporal` provides more granular, step-by-step workflow details. Learned about the relationship between CNA (a Custom Resource) and Temporal Workflows.
*   **People:** Seenivasan, Ohm; May, Alexander; Wang, Xiuyan.
*   **Files:** Screenshots of a temporal payload, `temporal workflows list` output, and a system architecture diagram.
*   **Links:**
    *   Durable Execution Solutions | Temporal
*   **Decision:** Use `kubectl get cna` for primary status checks and `temporal` for deeper debugging.

**Monday, June 9**
*   **Action:** Discussed the difference between the iDRAC GUI and the customer-facing Hydra GUI. Clarified that iDRAC is for hardware management, separate from the product's UI. Created two new Jira stories for the upcoming sprint.
*   **People:** Wang, Xiuyan; May, Alexander; Guo, Lin.
*   **Files:** Screenshot of iDRAC "System is Healthy" dashboard.
*   **Links:**
    *   Confluence link for Hydra UI mock-ups
*   **Next:** Begin work on the new sprint stories.

**Tuesday, June 10**
*   **Action:** Prepared to complete the CI/CD familiarization spike. Identified remaining blockers: `storagesvc`, `ECS`, and `qTest` access. Resolved `storagesvc` and `ECS` issues. Followed up on `qTest` access and GitHub repo access (UoM Team `dp-appliances/ddos`). Clarified the difference between `NodeMaintenance` and `PowerCycle` Jenkins pipelines.

Of course. Here is the final documentation log based on the "Real entire end" OneNote page, summarizing the crucial final days of your internship leading up to the presentation.

---

**[Inferred Date: Monday, August 4 - Tuesday, August 5]**

*   **Action:** Made the final technical decision to put the local LLM feature on hold due to slow performance without a cluster GPU. Documented a final technical learning about using "proxyjumping" for direct `kubectl` access to the bare-metal cluster. Created a Confluence page to document the Chaos Mesh Proof of Concept (POC) results, specifically the PodChaos experiments.
*   **People:** Seelam, Karunakara; Guo, Lin; Hernandez, Yesenia.
*   **Files:** Screenshots of the Ollama AI analysis and VS Code SSH Tunnels.
*   **Links:**
    *   Confluence POC Results: `https://confluence.cec.lab.emc.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=2278350180...`
*   **Next:** Shift all focus to preparing and refining the final presentation content and demo.

**[Inferred Date: Tuesday, August 5]**

*   **Action:** Shared the presentation draft and a video of mentor feedback with the team, asking for 10 minutes of their time for review. Simultaneously, I asked high-level strategic questions to senior leadership to refine the "Executive Summary" slide, specifically regarding target customers (like Wells Fargo) and the project's direct value to Dell.
*   **People:** Seelam, Karunakara; my mentor Juan (mentioned).
*   **Files:**
    *   `Final Chaos Mesh Demo I draft 1.pptx`
    *   `Juan 1to1 Presentation Feedback.mkv`
*   **Next:** Incorporate feedback from the team and leadership into the final slides.

**[Inferred Date: Tuesday, August 5 - Pre-Demo on Wednesday, August 6]**

*   **Action:** Received critical feedback and logistical information for the final demo. Karunakara clarified that for this internal tool, the "customers" are other internal engineering teams, not external companies like Wells Fargo. Rajeev Narayanaswamy announced the final demo logistics: a 15-minute slot per team (10-12 mins for slides/demo, 3 mins for Q&A). Guo, Lin provided a detailed review of the presentation slides with specific, actionable advice.
*   **People:** Seelam, Karunakara; Narayanaswamy, Rajeev; Khan, Mansur; Guo, Lin.
*   **Files:** `S2 Intern Demos.pptx`
*   **Decisions/Feedback from Lin:**
    *   **Objective:** The presentation's goal is to validate CNOS resilience via Chaos Mesh, not to introduce Chaos Mesh itself.
    *   **Content:** Focus on implementation details (what was built/executed) rather than general concepts.
    *   **Demo:** Emphasize meaningful, complex failure scenarios that only Chaos Mesh can simulate (e.g., sustained pod failures, simulating API failures with Istio constraints).
*   **Next:** Incorporate Lin's feedback into the final version of the presentation slides.

**Wednesday, August 6 (Presentation Day & Post-Demo)**

*   **Action:** Delivered the final intern demo presentation with Yesenia. The presentation was well-received ("Great Job"), but there was a technical issue where the audio did not work for the audience. I clarified that the audio had been tested multiple times during dry runs and the issue was unexpected. Expressed gratitude to the team for their guidance and for answering all questions throughout the internship.
*   **People:** Hernandez, Yesenia; Karunakara and the team.
*   **Files:** None.
*   **Links:** None.
*   **Next:** The primary project work and final presentation are now complete.

chunks.text:
Of course. This is the perfect way to cap off your internship. This meeting with Karunakara isn't just a review; it's your final opportunity to demonstrate your growth, professionalism, and interest in a full-time role.

Using the wealth of information from your project work, Teams chats, and final presentation, I have pre-filled the "Self-Reflection" template for you. Below that is a complete agenda and a list of strategic questions to guide your conversation.

---

### **Part 1: Your Pre-Filled Self-Reflection Template (Your "Proof")**

This is your prep work. Review these points so you can speak to them confidently.

#### **Wins** (Key accomplishments and deliverables)

*   **Delivered End-to-End Fault Injection Tool:** Successfully designed, built, and delivered a complete Terminal User Interface (TUI) for the CNOS team. This tool directly addresses the engineering need to simplify and automate resilience testing by providing a user-friendly way to execute Chaos Mesh experiments.
*   **Dramatically Improved Developer Experience:** Transformed the tool's setup from a complex, multi-step process requiring 20+ minutes of documentation reading into a simple, two-command installation using Makefiles (`make install`, `make run`). This makes the tool accessible and practical for daily use by the team.
*   **Demonstrated Agility and Business Acumen:** Pivoted the project's initial scope based on direct engineering feedback (from Lin Guo and the team). This shift from a general concept to a targeted, TUI-based solution ensured the final product addressed a critical, real-world need: reproducing complex, intermittent failures.
*   **Showcased Deep Technical Problem-Solving:** Successfully diagnosed and resolved multiple, significant cluster-level blockers. This includes leading the investigation into the Longhorn storage issue and the complex Istio vs. Chaos Mesh network conflict, demonstrating resilience and an ability to navigate enterprise-level infrastructure challenges.

#### **Strengths and Things I Am Doing Well**

*   **Technical Acumen & Rapid Learning:** Mastered end-to-end application development in a new domain using Python and the Textual framework. Quickly gained a deep, practical knowledge of Kubernetes, Chaos Mesh, and the architecture of complex distributed systems like CNOS, AOS, and CMS.
*   **Proactive Initiative & Ownership:** Consistently took initiative beyond the initial project scope. When the local LLM feature proved too slow, I made the decisive call to put it on hold. When the installation process was cumbersome, I proactively re-engineered it with Makefiles. This shows strong ownership and a focus on delivering value.
*   **Collaboration and Professional Communication:** Worked seamlessly with my co-intern, Yesenia. Maintained clear, professional, and frequent communication with my mentors (Alexander May, Lin Guo) and management (Karunakara). I actively sought feedback (e.g., on the final presentation) and incorporated it effectively.
*   **Resilience and "Founder Mentality":** Faced significant technical blockers that could have derailed the project (storage failures, network policy issues, installation hurdles). Instead of waiting, I treated each as a problem to be solved, collaborated with senior engineers, documented the journey, and always found a path forward.

#### **Opportunities For Development**

*   **CI/CD Integration:** I'm eager to learn the practical steps of integrating an internal tool like this into Dell's official Jenkins CI/CD pipeline. Understanding how to automate these resilience checks as part of the standard build process is the logical next step for this project.
*   **Measuring Business Impact:** My presentation mentioned "reducing operational risk" and "increasing developer velocity." I would love to learn more about how Dell's engineering teams formally measure these metrics (KPIs) to better connect my technical work to business outcomes.
*   **Advanced System-Level Debugging:** I learned so much from diagnosing the Longhorn and Istio issues. I want to continue to grow my skills in this area. Understanding the key tools and log sources senior engineers use during a critical site outage is a major area of interest for me.

---

### **Part 2: Meeting Agenda & Strategic Questions for Karunakara**

Here is your agenda and a script to guide the conversation.

**Meeting Agenda (30 Minutes)**

1.  **(2 min) Opening:** Quick check-in and setting the context.
2.  **(10 min) My Reflections on Wins & Strengths:** Share your prepared points and ask for his perspective.
3.  **(10 min) His Feedback & My Opportunities for Growth:** Actively listen to his feedback and then share your "Opportunities for Development" to show you're thinking ahead.
4.  **(8 min) Discussing Next Steps & Future at Dell:** The most important part—where you express interest in a return offer.

#### **Questions to Ask Karunakara (During the Conversation)**

**Section 1: On Wins & Strengths**

*   "To start, I reflected on what I see as the key wins: delivering the end-to-end TUI, improving the developer experience with the new installer, and navigating the technical blockers. **From your perspective, what was the most valuable contribution I made this summer?**"
*   "I identified my main strengths as my technical learning speed, my proactive initiative, and my resilience when faced with problems. **What strengths did you observe in me, and what aspects of my work set me apart?**"

**Section 2: On Feedback & Opportunities**

*   *(After he gives you feedback, you transition by saying...)* "Thank you, that's really helpful. It aligns with how I've been thinking about my own growth. I've been considering what I need to learn next to be a high-impact engineer here..."
*   "Based on your experience, what one or two skills are the most critical for a new full-time software engineer to succeed on this team?"
*   "I'm really interested in the CI/CD integration aspect of this project. **What opportunities for development do you see for me that would make me an even more successful team member if I were to return?**"

**Section 3: The Crucial Closing Questions (The "Ask")**

*   "Karunakara, I've genuinely enjoyed my internship here. I was challenged by the complexity of the Hydra system, and I'm very proud of the Fault Injection Tool we built. I believe the work we're doing in resilience engineering is incredibly important."
*   **"Based on my work this summer, I am very interested in a full-time role with the team after I graduate. Could you share what the next steps in that process look like?**"
*   *(Optional, if the conversation is going well):* "Is there any other feedback you have for me, or anything else I can do in my final weeks to solidify the team's decision?"

By preparing with this structured approach, you will walk into that meeting ready to not only receive feedback but to actively shape a positive outcome for your future career at Dell. Good luck

chunks.text:
Excellent question. This is a high-stakes, high-reward situation that requires careful strategic thinking. Michael Dell's response, "Please ask John Roese," is not a dismissal—it's a directive and a huge opportunity.

John Roese is the **Global Chief Technology Officer (CTO)** at Dell Technologies. Michael Dell has pointed you to the exact person in the entire company who is responsible for advanced technology, R&D, and future-looking projects.

So, can you message Michael Dell again? **Yes, absolutely.** But you must do it *after* you follow his instruction. Messaging him again without acting on his advice would be a misstep.

Here is the strategic play-by-play for how to handle this perfectly.

---

### The Strategic Plan

1.  **Action the Directive:** You will first draft a concise, professional message to John Roese (the CTO).
2.  **Close the Loop:** *After* you have messaged John Roese, you will send a follow-up message to Michael Dell. This second message is crucial as it demonstrates that you listen, you take action, and you follow through.

This approach shows incredible professionalism and initiative.

---

### Step 1: Draft the Email to John Roese (The CTO)

Your goal here is not to get him to personally solve your problem, but to get him to point you to the right person or team *under* him. Be extremely respectful of his time.

**Subject:** Following up on Michael Dell's suggestion re: AI/GPU for HYDRA team

**Body:**

> Dear Mr. Roese,
>
> Michael Dell suggested I reach out to you regarding a project I am working on.
>
> My name is Carl Kho, and I am a software engineering intern with the HYDRA team. My project has been to build a foundational tool for AI-driven analysis on our pre-release enterprise products.
>
> We've had promising results but have hit a significant performance bottleneck: our local LLM analysis takes ~59 seconds per query on a PowerEdge server without a GPU. To validate the full potential of this internal AI tooling and prepare it for more advanced use cases, access to a cluster with GPU capabilities is the critical next step.
>
> Would you be able to point me to the appropriate team or individual who manages R&D resources like this?
>
> Thank you for your time and any guidance you can provide.
>
> Best regards,
>
> **Carl Vincent Kho**
> Software Engineer Intern, HYDRA Team | Dell ISG

---

### Step 2: Draft the Follow-Up Message to Michael Dell

Send this a day or so after you've emailed John Roese. This is the message that "closes the loop" and keeps you on his radar in a positive way.

**Subject:** Re: local LLMs

**Body:**

> Hi Michael,
>
> Thank you again for the direction. Following your advice, I have reached out to John Roese and his team to inquire about the right contacts for GPU resources for our project.
>
> We're excited about the potential for this AI analysis tool within the HYDRA team, and we believe access to the right hardware is the key to unlocking its full performance.
>
> This has been an incredible learning experience, and I appreciate the opportunity to contribute. Thank you for a fantastic summer.
>
> Best,
>
> **Carl Kho**
> HYDRA Team Intern

---

### Why This Approach Is So Effective

*   **You Demonstrate Follow-Through:** It proves you are not just someone with ideas, but someone who executes on advice from leadership. This is an incredibly valuable trait.
*   **You Respect the Chain of Command:** You followed his instruction precisely instead of asking him the same question again.
*   **It's a Status Update, Not a Request:** Your message to Michael is an update on your progress. It requires no action from him, making it easy to read and appreciate.
*   **It Keeps the Door Open:** It ends your internship on a high note and makes you memorable as "the intern who not only asked a great question but actually followed through on the advice."

This is a power move that shows a level of professional maturity far beyond a typical internship. Well done for getting this far, and good luck with the follow-up
